## ğŸŒ The IPCC: Scientific Foundation

- The **Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)** is the **United Nations body** that provides policymakers with regular scientific assessments on climate change.  
- It **synthesizes** findings from thousands of peer-reviewed studies â€” it does **not conduct original research**.  
- Its reports provide the **scientific foundation** for international agreements like the **Paris Agreement**.  
- [IPCC AR6 (2021)](https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/) confirms:

    <br><span style="font-size:1.5rem;">â€” IPCC AR6 (2021)</span>
  </blockquote>
</div>



## ğŸ”® How the IPCC Projects the Future

- The IPCC combines:
  1. **Climate Models** â†’ simulate how greenhouse gases affect temperature and sea level.  
  2. **Socioeconomic Scenarios** â†’ describe how population, energy, and policy evolve.

# **The Social Cost of Carbon (SCC)** {background-color="#1c4982"}



## ğŸ’° Unpacking the Social Cost of Carbon

<div align="center">

{{< video https://youtu.be/nDuDUPfJLU0?si=AD0kT4kxeHjpIWCp width="1200" height="600" >}}

## ğŸŒ What Is the Social Cost of Carbon?

> **Definition:**  
> The **Social Cost of Carbon (SCC)** is the **monetary estimate** of the economic damages caused by emitting **one additional ton of COâ‚‚** into the atmosphere.

- The "**social cost of carbon**" (SCC) is the present value of future damages from one additional ton of CO2 emissions.
  - Central tool in **Cost-Benefit Analysis** of regulations  
  - Expressed in **\$ per ton of COâ‚‚**
  - Links **climate impacts** to **economic valuation**
  - Used by **governments and firms** to guide **climate-related policy and investment decisions**


## ğŸ§® How the SCC Is Used in Policy

  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
#### **If emissions increase...**
â†’ Multiply extra tons of COâ‚‚ by the SCC

::: {.column width="50%"}
#### **If emissions decrease...**
â†’ Multiply reduced tons of COâ‚‚ by the SCC

## ğŸ§© Seven Key Ingredients of the SCC

## ğŸ” Seven Key Ingredients Explained

<span class="fragment">
1ï¸âƒ£ **Socioeconomic and Emissions Pathways**  
   Project how the global economy and emissions evolve under different scenarios.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
2ï¸âƒ£ **Climate Model**  
   Quantifies how additional COâ‚‚ affects temperature and sea level.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
3ï¸âƒ£ **Damage Function**  
   Links physical climate impacts to economic outcomesâ€”agriculture, health, energy, and property losses.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
4ï¸âƒ£ **Discounting**  
   Converts future damages into todayâ€™s monetary value; the discount rate reflects how we value future generations.    
</span>

## ğŸ” Seven Key Ingredients Explained

<span class="fragment">
5ï¸âƒ£ **Equity**  
   Accounts for how climate damages affect regions and income groups differently.  
</span>  

<span class="fragment">
6ï¸âƒ£ **Global vs. Domestic Damages**  
   Determines whether to value global harms or focus only on national impactsâ€”an ethical and policy choice.  
</span>

<span class="fragment">
7ï¸âƒ£ **Uncertainty**  
   Reflects the wide range of possible outcomes from complex climate and economic systems.   
</span> 



## ğŸ”¬ Modern IAM Models

- Several major **Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs)** are used to estimate the SCC â€” including **DICE**, **FUND**, and **PAGE**.  
- A new-generation IAM, the **Greenhouse Gas Impact Value Estimator (GIVE)**, was developed by **Resources for the Future (RFF)** and **UC Berkeley** (Rennert et al., *Nature*, 2022).  
- The GIVE model integrates the latest data on **climate science**, **economic damages**, and **discounting**.  
- Updated estimate:  
<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>

  $$ \text{SCC} = \$185\ \text{per ton COâ‚‚} $$
- Adopted by the **U.S. EPA (2023)** as the central value â†’ **â‰ˆ \$190 per ton**.  
<!-- - This marks a **major increase** from earlier federal estimates (â‰ˆ \$50 per ton). -->

- ğŸ”º [A recent 2025 study](https://sites.google.com/site/adrienbilal) finds SCC values approaching **\$1,500 per ton** (at a 2% discount rate) when accounting for **global temperature shocks**, far significantly higher than previous work.

- Climate damages are projected to cost the U.S. economy **~1â€“4% of GDP annually by 2100** â€” equivalent to **\$250 billionâ€“\$1 trillion per year (in todayâ€™s dollars)**.  
- Thatâ€™s **comparable to, or larger than, the entire U.S. defense budget**.

## ğŸŒ Global vs. Domestic Damages

- **Global SCC:** Reflects worldwide climate impacts  
- **Domestic SCC:** Includes only **U.S. (or national)** damages  
- Because **COâ‚‚ mixes globally**, every ton emitted anywhere affects the whole planet.  
- A **domestic-only** approach captures only **10â€“20%** of total global damages.  

<span class="fragment">
â†’ Choice of scope reflects **policy values**:  
Do we count only national welfare, or **shared global responsibility**?
</span>


## âš–ï¸ Ethical and Policy Implications
<div style="display:block; margin:25px;"></div>

### ğŸŒ Global Approach
- Recognizes the **shared nature of the atmosphere**  
- Aligns with **international cooperation** (e.g., Paris Agreement)  
- Justifies **stronger domestic action**, since it values global welfare  

<div style="display:block; margin:25px;"></div>

### ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Domestic Approach
- Focuses narrowly on **national self-interest**  
- Yields **lower SCC values** and weaker incentives to cut emissions  
- Often used for **legal or regulatory consistency** in federal rulemaking  


## ğŸŒ Why a Global Perspective Matters

> â€œCOâ‚‚ knows no borders.  
> A ton emitted in New York warms the planet just as much as one emitted in New Delhi.  
> The true cost of carbon is **global**, even when policies are made domestically.â€

- **Global SCC â‰ˆ \$190/ton** (EPA, 2023)  
- **U.S.-only SCC â‰ˆ \$20â€“\$40/ton** â€” just a small share of total global harm  
- Because climate impacts are **shared worldwide**, no nation bears the full cost of its own emissions  
<span class="fragment">
â†’ **Global cooperation is essential** for efficient and fair climate policy
</span>

## âš ï¸ Uncertainty


<div style="text-align:center; width: 66.7%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/give-sdr-dist.png" alt="Observed vs reconstructed warming; attribution with human & natural vs natural-only forcing" style="max-width: 1000px; width: 100%;">
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

Because climate, economic growth, and technology are unpredictable:

- Models simulate **thousands of futures**  
- SCC is best viewed as a **range** rather than a single value  
- Analysts often use a **central case** + â€œhigh-impact scenarioâ€



## ğŸ§­ Policy Evolution of the SCC
<div style="display:block; margin:-12.5px;"></div>

- **1981:** Benefitâ€“cost analysis **required for all major federal rules**  
- **2008:** Courts ruled that agencies **must include the SCC** ([*Center for Biological Diversity v. NHTSA*](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/us-9th-circuit/1024716.html))  
- **2010â€“2016:** **Obama administration** established the **Interagency Working Group (IWG)** â†’ developed a **global SCC** (â‰ˆ **\$50/ton COâ‚‚**) with SDRs of **2.5%, 3%, and 5%**
- **2017:** **Trump administration** **disbanded the IWG** â†’ adopted **U.S.-only SCC** with **high SDRs (3% & 7%)**, lowering values to **\$1â€“\$7 per ton**
- **2021:** **Biden administration** **restored the IWG** and reinstated the **interim global SCC = \$51/ton** (2016 value, inflation-adjusted)  
- **2023:** **EPA updated** the estimate to **\$190/ton** using the **GIVE model**  
- **2025:** **Trump administration initiated a major rollback** of SCC methodology under a broader **energy deregulation agenda**
